Title: The Afferent Input to the Magnocellular Division of the Mediodorsal Thalamic Nucleus in the Monkey, Macaca fascicularis
Abstract:
"The origin and termination of fibers to the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus, especially those to the medial, magnocellular part of the
nucleus (MDm), have been studied using anterograde and retrograde axonal tracing methods, as well as electro-physiological recording.The results indicate that in addition to its well-known connections to and from the prefrontal cortex, MDm receives fibers from many parts of the basal forebrain, including the ventral pallidum and other parts of the substantia innominata, the amygdaloid complex, the primary olfactory cortex, entorhinal and perirhinal cortex, and the cortex at the pole of the temporal lobe. Lighter projections arise in the subiculum, the ventral insula, and the superior and inferior temporal gyri. The cells that project to MDm tend to be large, polymorphic neurons. Throughout most of the basal forebrain they are diffusely distributed through several nuclei or cortical layers, without obvious relation to nuclear or laminar boundaries. The major exception to this is in the ventral pallidum, where there is a dense concentration of
cells that project to MDm. The lateral part of the mediodorsal nucleus (MDl) receives few if any fibers from the basal forebrain and temporal lobe, but is innervated by several brainstem structures, especially the superior colliculus, the substantia nigra, the medial vestibular nucleus, and the midbrain tegmental fields. In MDm, the fibers are distributed in irregular patches. Three-dimensional analysis indicates that these patches are often clustered into separate bands or columns at different anteroposterior levels. In addition, the strongest projections from the three major regions that innervate MDm are organized in a complex three-dimensional pattern. First, the fibers from the amygdaloid nuclei terminate most heavily (but not exclusively) in the rostral third of MDm. The parvicellular accessory basal amygdaloid nucleus and the amygdalohippocampal area project principally to the dorsal part of the nucleus. The parvicellular
basal nucleus and the periamygdaloid cortex project to the ventromedial quadrant of MDm; and the magnocellular basal nucleus, the magnocellular accessory basal nucleus, and the lateral nucleus all project to the ventrolateral quadrant. Second, the substantia innominata projects preferentially to the caudal part of MDm. The medial part of the substantia innominata, especially the ventral pallidum, innervates the dorsomedial quadrant, while more caudal and lateral areas of this region project  ventro-
laterally. Third, the projections arising from the entorhinal and other temporal cortical areas terminate primarily in the mid-rostrocaudal level of MDm."

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "The lateral part of MD (MDl, including Olszewski's parvicellular  and multiform divisions) ... The medial portion of MD (MDm, Olszewski's magnocellular division) ..."

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It hasn't been stated that the parcellation scheme of RA87 for the amygdaloid complex and that for cortical temporal areas equals that of AP84, but it is quite probable, because (i) D.G. Amaral and J.L. Price are authors of both papers, (ii) the areas/ nuclei have approximately the same location, and (iii) and most of the areas and nuclei have the same abbreviations. But the most important hint that both parcellation schemes may equals is that in both papers the same figure (with the same location and same names of the injection sites) has been used (compare Fig. 1 of AP84 and Fig. 15 of RAP87).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The nomenclature used for the nuclei in the thalamus largely follows that proposed by Olszewski ('52)."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: The identity of these areas is supported by the comparision of RAP87's Figure 1 and 2 with corresponding sections of Olszewski ('52).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The medial portion of MD (MDm, Olszewski's magnocellular division), ... the medial part (MDm) corresponds to Olszewski's magnocellular division."
"... in the hippocampal formation (especially the subiculum)"
"Within the mediodorsal nucleus (MD), medial and lateral segments will be referred to; the medial part (MDm) ... [and] the lateral part (MDl)..."
"Within the mediodorsal nucleus (MD), medial and lateral segments will be referred to; the medial part (MDm) ... [and] the lateral part (MDl)..."
"The lateral part of MD (MDl, including Olszewski's parvicellular and multiform divisions) ... while the lateral part (MDl) corresponds to his parvicellular and multiform divisions."
"The lateral part of MD (MDl, including Olszewski's parvicellular and multiform divisions) ... while the lateral part (MDl) corresponds to his parvicellular and multiform divisions."
"... the ventral pallidum in the monkey has been identified in the rostral and medial part of the substantia innominata."
"... the ventral pallidum in the monkey has been identified in the rostral and medial part of the substantia innominata."

"In the remaining portions of the substantia innominata, the areas containing the colinergic cell groups CH2, CH3, and Ch4 as delineated by Mesulam et al.,'83) were designated as the nucleus of the vertical and horizontal limbs of the diagonal band (NVDB and NHDB) and the nucleus basalis of Meynert (NBM), respectively."

"In the remaining portions of the substantia innominata, the areas containing the colinergic cell groups CH2, CH3, and Ch4 as delineated by Mesulam et al.,'83) were designated as the nucleus of the vertical and horizontal limbs of the diagonal band (NVDB and NHDB) and the nucleus basalis of Meynert (NBM), respectively."

"In the remaining portions of the substantia innominata, the areas containing the colinergic cell groups CH2, CH3, and Ch4 as delineated by Mesulam et al.,'83) were designated as the nucleus of the vertical and horizontal limbs of the diagonal band (NVDB and NHDB) and the nucleus basalis of Meynert (NBM), respectively."

It hasn't been stated that the parcellation scheme of RA87  for the amygdaloid complex and that for cortical temporal areas equals that of AP84, but it is quite probable, because (i) D.G. "... the ventral pallidum in the monkey has been identified in the rostral and medial part of the substantia innominata."

@Injections.Citation: "In a second group of experiments (DM11 and PRM1) ... the injections are centered in the parvicellular division of the accessory basal nucleus, with additional inolvement of the amygdalohippocampal area and the posterior cortical nucleus (in DM11), or the posterior cortical nucleus and the dorsal portion of the periamygdaloid cortex (in PRM1; Fig.15)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In a second group of experiments (DM11 and PRM1) the labeled axons are located in the dorsal part of MDm."

@Injections.Citation: "In a third group of experiments ... the injection sites are in the deeper amygdaloid nuclei ... In DM19-rt and DM29-lt, the injections are centered in the lateral nucleus (Fig.15)..."
@Injections.Comments: The injection involves also the white matter below the lateral amygdaloid nucleus.

@Injections.Citation: "Three experiments are availaible in which the injection is placed laterally in the rostral half of the entorhinal cortex... experiment DM25 has an injection centered slightly rostromedially to that in DM38..."
@Injections.Comments: Injections in the entorhinal, perirhinal, and temporal polar cortices

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In all three cases [DM38, DM25, and MF6] the axonal label is ditributed in several patches situated medially in MDm, at the mid-rostrocaudal level."

@Injections.Citation: "A third experiment (DM27, not illustrated) has an injection that selectively involves the amygdalohippocampal area..."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In this case [DM27], as in DM11, patches of silver grains are found in the dorsomedial part of MDm, and there is also a small seperate patch of label in the caudal part of the nucleus."

@Injections.Citation: "In a third group of experiments ... the injection sites are in the deeper amygdaloid nuclei ... In DM19-rt and DM29-lt, the injections are centered in the lateral nucleus (Fig.15)..."
"In ... DM31, the pavicellular division of the basal nucleus (but not the periamygdaliod cortex) is involved in the injection site (Fig.15)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation:
"In ... DM31 (Fig.18)... The pattern of labeling in this case is similar to that in DM34-lt."

@Injections.Citation: "In DM34-lt the injection site is centered in the periamygdaloid cortex (Fig.15) and also involved the parvicellulardivision of the basal nucleus as well as the parvicellular division of the accessory nucleus."

"Three experiments are availiable in which the injection is placed laterally in the rostral half of the entorhinal cortex... experiment DM25 has an injection centered slightly rostromedially to that in DM38..."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "[In DM42] Patches of labeling are found predominatly in the ventromedial quadrant of the middle one third of MD, allthough samller seperate patches are found more caudally."

@Injections.Citation: "In DM46 multiple injections of tritiated amino acids were placed in the cortex at the anterior pole of the temporal lobe."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Patches of labeled axons are distributed rather widely through the MD. The heaviest labeling is found in the middle one-third of MDm."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In all three cases [DM38, DM25, and MF6] the axonal label is ditributed in several patches situated medially in MDm, at the mid-rostrocaudal level."

@Injections.Citation: "In a second group of experiments (DM11 and PRM1) ... the injections are centered in the parvicellular division of the accessory basal nucleus, with additional inolvement of the amygdalohippocampal area and the posterior cortical nucleus (in DM11), or the posterior cortical nucleus and the dorsal portion of the periamygdaloid cortex (in PRM1; Fig.15)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In a second group of experiments (DM11 and PRM1) the labeled axons are located in the dorsal part of MDm... The largest and densest patches of label in these cases are located in the rostral and dorsal part of MDm, with lighter ventromedial and ventrolateral extensions that form apartial ring around MDm."

@Injections.Citation: "In experiment PRM19 the injection is centered rostrally in the ventral pallidum, with some involvement of the nucleus accumbens."
"In PRM4 a single injection is centered rostromedially, in the ventral pallidum."

"In the two other cases (PRM 15 and PRM 10), the injections are centered in the intralaminar paracentral nucleus and involve the ventral and lateral portions of the rostral MD." (p. 179)
"However, in PRM 10, in which the ventromedial nucleus is included to the injection site (as well as MD, the submedial nucleus, and the paracentral nucleus),..." (p. 185)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Another notable difference is that while in PRM 17 a few lightly labeled cells are found in the central and medial amygdaloid nuclei, and in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, these are not present in PRM 14, PRM 18 or the other brains." (pp. 181-182)

"In experiment PRM10 (rostroventral injection, also involving the paracentral and submedial nuclei) most of the labeled cells are located ventral to the principal sulcus... The largest number of cells are found in area 45, and in a band extending caudally through area 12 into the agranular and dysgranular insula... there are some cells more medially in areas 11 and 13. Laterally, many labeled cells are located dorsally in areas 46 and 8, and some are also found in area 24.
"PRM10 (not illustrated), in which the injection is in the ventral edge of MDm, has many positive cells in the lateral substantia inominata but very few in the ventral pallidum."

@Injections.Citation: "In three of these [WGA-HRP injections] (PRM 14, 17 and 18), the injection sites are centered in the medial part of MD at different rostrocaudal levels; in PRM18 the injection involves the adjacent part of MDl."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation:
"A comparison of experiment PRM 17 with other cases with smaller injections suggests that the projections from the basal forebrain and temporal lobe structures to MDm are spatially organized. Thus, PRM 14 (Fig. 8), in which the injection site is in the more rostral part of MDm, has relatively more cells in the amygdaloid complex and fewer cells in the ventral pallidum or the temporal cortex. ...PRM 14 and PRM 21 (Figs. 8, 10), which have injections in the dorsal part of MDM, contain more labeled cells in the medial part of the substantia innominata, especially theventral pallidum, than in the lateral part of this region." (p. 181)
"Another notable difference is that while in PRM 17 a few lightly labeled cells are found in the central and medial amygdaloid nuclei, and in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, these are not present in PRM 14, PRM 18 or the other brains." (pp. 181-182)

@LabelledSites_Data.Comments: Additional information about the density of labeling can be found in the description of figure 8.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Thus, PRM14 (Fig.8), in which the injection injection is in a more rostral part of MDm, has relatively more cells in the amygdaloid complex and fewer cells in the ventral pallidum or the temporal cortex."

"In eperiment PRM14 (rostrocaudal injection), labeled cells are confined to a relatively small area that includes rostrodorsal and ventromedial portions of area 10, most of area 14, and the lateral orbital sulcus (including the medial part of area 12) and the lateral part of area 13 (Figs. 12, 13). This labeling continues caudally into the rostral part of the agranular insula area, and rostrally into a small strip of labeled cells in area 32 and 13a."

@Injections.Citation: "In the two other cases (PRM 15 and PRM 10), the injections are centered in the intralaminar paracentral nucleus and involve the ventral and lateral portions of the rostral MD."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In PRM15 (extreme lateral injection) most of the retrogradely filled cells are found in area 8 along the rostral bank of the arcuate sulcus and in area 6 near the precentral dimple. Labelled cells are also found caudally in area 46 and dorsally in area 45."

"In this brain [PRM15] there are few positive cells int the basal forebrain, the hypothalamus, the ventral tegmental area, or parabrachial nucleus... the superior colliculus, the vestibular nucleus, and the lateral part of the substantia nigra.

"Another notable difference is that while in PRM 17 a few lightly labeled cells are found in the central and medial amygdaloid nuclei, and in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, these are not present in PRM 14, PRM 18 or the other brains." (pp. 181-182)
"...Many retrogradely labeled cells are observed in th emedial aspect of the substantia innominata (including ventral pallidum) with a smaller number in the amygdaloid complex.
...Heavy retrograde labling is found in the pyramidal cell layer of the hippocampus and subiculum in this brain, but this may be due largely to involvement of the fornix by the injection, since few labeled cells are seen in this lamina in the more discretely injected cases. On the other hand, in those cases a small number of positive cells are present in the deeper laminae of the subiculum, and anterograde tracing experiments confirm that MDm receives a light and patchy projection from this part of the hippocampal formation (Amaral and Insausti, unpublished observation." (p. 182)

@Injections.Citation: "In three of these [WGA-HRP injections] (PRM 14, 17 and 18), the injection sites are centered in the medial part of MD at different rostrocaudal levels; in PRM18 the injection involves the adjacent part of MDl...The injection [in PRM17] is relatively large and is centered at about the midrostrocaudal level od MDm; it also slightly involves MDl and the midline thalamic nuclei. "

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In PRM17 (large mid-rostrocaudal injection) there is substantial large cell labeling at the frontal pole, and cells are labeled in area 14, most of area 10 exept the frontal pole, area 32, and the rostroventral part of area 24. In the orbital cortex, most of the areas 11, 14, 13, 13a, and the medial part of area 12 contain labeled cells. Positive cells area also present more caudally in the agranular insular. On the lateral surface, retrogradely filled cells are present in the rostral part of area 46."
"PRM17... had the most extensive labeling in basal forebrain structures... "

"Retrogradely labeled cells are also found in several structures of the temporal lobe, especially the primary olfactory cortical areas, all nuclei of the amygdaloid complex, the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices, and the temporal polar cortex (Fig. 5). There are also labeled cells in the cortex of the rostral inferior and superior temporal gyri and the ventral insula, and in the hippocampal formation (especially the subiculum). The cells are scattered diffusely within this wide region, and are not restricted to specific cortical layers; some cells are located in the subcortical white matter. Labeling in all temporal lobe structures is bilateral, with approximately one-quarter the number of labeled cells found on the contralateral side." (p.179)
"Another notable difference is that while in PRM 17 a few lightly labeled cells are found in the central and medial amygdaloid nuclei, and in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, these are not present in PRM 14, PRM 18 or the other brains." (pp. 181-182)

"Experiment PRM18 (caudal injection, with slight involvement of MDl) has labeled cortical cells that tend to be located more caudally than in PRM17 (Fig.13). On the lateral surface of the frontal cortex, label is found in area 46..."

@Injections.Citation: "In one experiment (PRM21), the injection site is centered dorsolaterally in MD and involves portions of both its medial and lateral divisions, as well as the intralaminar nucleus centralis superior."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "PRM14 and PRM21 (Figs.8, 10), which have injections in the dorsolateral part of MDm, contain more labeled cells in the medial part of the substantia innominata, especially the ventral pallidum, than in the lateral part of this region."

"Another notable difference is that while in PRM 17 a few lightly labeled cells are found in the central and medial amygdaloid nuclei, and in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, these are not present in PRM 14, PRM 18 or the other brains." (pp. 181-182)

In experiment PRM 21 (dorsal injection involving parts of MDm and MDl) most of the labeled cells are located on the dorsolateral surfaceof the cortex in areas 9, 10, and 46, with some cells on the medial surface in areas 24 and 32. As in PRM14 ... labeled cells in the lateral bank of the orbital sulcus (mostly in area 12).

publication.title: The Afferent Input to the Magnocellular Division of the Mediodorsal Thalamic Nucleus in the Monkey, Macaca fascicularis
publication.abstract:
"The origin and termination of fibers to the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus, especially those to the medial, magnocellular part of the
nucleus (MDm), have been studied using anterograde and retrograde axonal tracing methods, as well as electro-physiological recording.The results indicate that in addition to its well-known connections to and from the prefrontal cortex, MDm receives fibers from many parts of the basal forebrain, including the ventral pallidum and other parts of the substantia innominata, the amygdaloid complex, the primary olfactory cortex, entorhinal and perirhinal cortex, and the cortex at the pole of the temporal lobe. Lighter projections arise in the subiculum, the ventral insula, and the superior and inferior temporal gyri. The cells that project to MDm tend to be large, polymorphic neurons. Throughout most of the basal forebrain they are diffusely distributed through several nuclei or cortical layers, without obvious relation to nuclear or laminar boundaries. The major exception to this is in the ventral pallidum, where there is a dense concentration of
cells that project to MDm. The lateral part of the mediodorsal nucleus (MDl) receives few if any fibers from the basal forebrain and temporal lobe, but is innervated by several brainstem structures, especially the superior colliculus, the substantia nigra, the medial vestibular nucleus, and the midbrain tegmental fields. In MDm, the fibers are distributed in irregular patches. Three-dimensional analysis indicates that these patches are often clustered into separate bands or columns at different anteroposterior levels. In addition, the strongest projections from the three major regions that innervate MDm are organized in a complex three-dimensional pattern. First, the fibers from the amygdaloid nuclei terminate most heavily (but not exclusively) in the rostral third of MDm. The parvicellular accessory basal amygdaloid nucleus and the amygdalohippocampal area project principally to the dorsal part of the nucleus. The parvicellular
basal nucleus and the periamygdaloid cortex project to the ventromedial quadrant of MDm; and the magnocellular basal nucleus, the magnocellular accessory basal nucleus, and the lateral nucleus all project to the ventrolateral quadrant. Second, the substantia innominata projects preferentially to the caudal part of MDm. The medial part of the substantia innominata, especially the ventral pallidum, innervates the dorsomedial quadrant, while more caudal and lateral areas of this region project  ventro-
laterally. Third, the projections arising from the entorhinal and other temporal cortical areas terminate primarily in the mid-rostrocaudal level of MDm."
